unnormalised: **Automotive: New Traffic Regulations Aim to Boost Road Safety**
normalised: Mumbai, October twenty sixth – The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has announced a series of updated traffic regulations, effective November fifteenth, aimed at enhancing road safety across India. These changes follow extensive consultations with institutions like I I T-Delhi and feedback from citizen groups.

unnormalised: Mumbai, Oct 26 – The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has announced a series of updated traffic regulations, effective November 15th, aimed at enhancing road safety across India. These changes follow extensive consultations with institutions like IIT-Delhi and feedback from citizen groups.
normalised: Key amendments include stricter enforcement of speed limits, particularly in urban areas, with fines for exceeding the limit by even five kilometer per hour. Rupee two thousand will be levied for first-time offenders, scaling up for repeat offenses. New regulations also mandate compulsory rear seatbelt usage, punishable with a Rupee one thousand fine.

unnormalised: Key amendments include stricter enforcement of speed limits, particularly in urban areas, with fines for exceeding the limit by even 5 kmph. Rs. 2000 will be levied for first-time offenders, scaling up for repeat offenses. New regulations also mandate compulsory rear seatbelt usage, punishable with a Rs. 1000 fine.
normalised: Inspired by the movie 'Highway', officials stressed the importance of safe driving habits for long-distance journeys. Specific emphasis is placed on the mandatory use of high-visibility jackets for two-wheeler riders after seven P M. Furthermore, revised rules outline procedures for accident reporting and victim compensation, aiming for quicker resolution and support. The updated guidelines are available on the Ministry's website in Hindi and English.
